footer.tagline: Building the coordination layer for multi-agent intelligence.

preview.banner: ColleaiQ is currently in development. We are running closed pilots with select partners.

hero.headline: When Artificial Intelligence behaves like a team.
hero.paragraph1: ColleaiQ provides the neuro-symbolic architecture required to manage specialized agents in high-stakes environments. The platform automates workflows by enforcing controlled inter-agent dialog and a "glassbox" reasoning process. This structure enables the solving of problems that exceed single-model context windows through secure MAS orchestration, integrated guardrails, and total operational traceability.
hero.latestPost: Field Notes: Why single-agent LLMs struggle with multi-step attacks →

visuals.hero_animation: [VISUAL_PLACEHOLDER: A minimalist, abstract network graph. Nodes (agents) light up in sequence—Research -> Plan -> Execute -> Verify—showing the flow of information rather than just a static connections.]

whatIs.headline: The Architecture
whatIs.description:
The core of ColleaiQ is a multi-agent system (MAS). We treat AI less like a magic box and more like a briefing room.

For any given task, we spin up a specific team of agents. In our security work, one agent might act as an attacker looking for a path, while another watches the logs to see if that path is visible. They share a memory and a context but have different instructions and learning paradigms.

This separation enforces logic, traceability, and security. When one agent has to explain its plan to another, it forces a level of reasoning that is hard to get from a single model.

whereWeStart.headline: Current Focus: Threat Simulation
whereWeStart.description:
Cybersecurity is our proving ground. The volume of new vulnerabilities (CVEs) and attack techniques makes it hard for human teams to test everything manually.

We are developing a platform that automates this testing in a safe way. Our agents act as a 'Red Team' inside a secure sandbox environment. They take a specific threat and try to execute it against a replica of a system. 

This isn't about guessing. It's about rehearsal. The system produces a step-by-step narrative of what happened, showing exactly where a defense held up and where it didn't.

whyStart.headline: Why Start Here?
whyStart.description:
We chose security because it is difficult. The environment is adversarial and the requirement for precision is high. If an agent hallucinates here, it is immediately obvious.

This constraint is good for us. It forces us to build systems that are grounded in evidence. We focus heavily on 'explainability'—ensuring that every decision the system makes can be traced back to a specific piece of data or a specific rule. That discipline will be essential as we eventually move into other fields.

visuals_middle.simulation_demo: [VISUAL_PLACEHOLDER: A split screen or 'terminal' view. On the left, a scrolling log of 'Agent Actions' (e.g., 'Scanning port...', ' attempting exploit...'). On the right, a clean, human-readable timeline being built in real-time based on those logs.]

whatUnlock.headline: Beyond Security
whatUnlock.description:
The patterns we are building for threat hunting apply elsewhere. Many industries rely on professionals who have to synthesize large amounts of information, check it against complex rules, and make a judgment call.

We are already exploring how these agent architectures translate to LegalTech and complex compliance work. The goal is always the same: to use agents to handle the complexity, so humans can make the final decision with better information.

howWeWork.headline: Working with the Lab
howWeWork.description:
We are an engineering team first. We work with partners who are interested in the mechanics of these systems as much as the output.

Our pilots are collaborative. We define a scope—usually a specific set of security scenarios or compliance checks—and we tune the agents to that environment. It helps us refine our coordination protocols, and it gives you a view into how autonomous agents handle your specific reality.

fromLab.headline: Field Notes
fromLab.postTitle: Building the 'Digital Colleague': Early lessons from agent coordination.
fromLab.postExcerpt: We found that giving agents specific 'personalities' and rigid boundaries actually improved their creativity in problem-solving. Here is what we learned from our latest simulation runs.

supporters.headline: They support us
supporters.description: We are based in Copenhagen and have strong ties to the university research community. We believe the best way to build safe AI is to do it in the open, with peer review and academic rigor.

whyDoing.headline: The Philosophy
whyDoing.description:
We are curious about the limits of autonomy. We want to know how far we can push a network of agents to solve problems on their own, while still keeping them safe and understandable.

It is a balancing act between the speed of automation and the judgment of human experts. We are building ColleaiQ to be the bridge between those two worlds.

finalCTA.headline: Interested in the research?
finalCTA.description: We are always looking for partners who have interesting problems and a high tolerance for technical depth. If you work in critical infrastructure, law, or compliance, let's have a conversation.

hero.headline: The Lab's Mission
hero.subtitle: Bringing the rigor of Multi-Agent Systems to the messiness of the real world.

vision.headline: The Next Step
vision.description: Single agents are interesting. Networks of agents are useful. We are working on the protocols that allow AI to scale horizontally—adding more specialized agents to solve harder problems.

platform.description: Our work focuses on 'bounded autonomy.' We give agents the freedom to explore solutions, but we enclose them in safety layers and strict reporting requirements. Transparency is the feature.

visuals_story.timeline_graphic: [VISUAL_PLACEHOLDER: A simple horizontal timeline. 2024: Single Agents. 2025: Multi-Agent Networks. Future: Cross-Domain Intelligence. Simple, clean lines.]

threat.title: Speed
threat.description: Attacks and vulnerabilities are moving faster than human teams can document them.

vulnerability.title: Complexity
vulnerability.description: Infrastructure has become too dense for any single person to hold in their head at once.

sovereignty.title: Control
sovereignty.description: European organizations need tools that are built with local compliance and data sovereignty as a baseline.

mission.description: To build tools that don't just automate tasks, but help us understand our own systems better.

hero.headline: The Methodology
hero.subtitle: How we structure autonomous threat hunting.

multiAgent.title: Specialized Agents
multiAgent.description: We break the problem down. One agent ingests Intelligence (CTI). Another plans the simulation. A third monitors the defense.

traceable.title: The Audit Trail
traceable.description: The system records the 'why' behind every action. This creates a graph of decisions that humans can review.

learning.title: The Feedback Loop
learning.description: When an analyst corrects an agent, that correction propagates through the system logic.

visuals_solution.architecture_diagram: [VISUAL_PLACEHOLDER: A schematic diagram. 'Input: CVE Description' -> 'Agent: Planner' -> 'Agent: Executor' -> 'Sandbox Environment' -> 'Output: Report'. Arrows showing the feedback loop.]

architecture.headline: The Workflow
architecture.redTeam: The Simulator: Takes a threat description and attempts to replicate it in a safe environment.
architecture.blueTeam: The Observer: Watches the simulation from the defender's perspective to see what signals are generated.
architecture.sandbox: The Sandbox: A contained, ephemeral environment where we can break things safely.
architecture.explainable: The Report: A consolidated view of the simulation, mapped to standard frameworks like MITRE ATT&CK.

benefits.headline: Why this approach?
benefits.benefit1: It moves testing off production systems.
benefits.benefit2: It provides evidence, not just theory.
benefits.benefit3: It handles the repetitive work of validating CVEs.
benefits.benefit5: It keeps the human expert in the driver's seat.
benefits.benefit6: It scales with the threat landscape.
benefits.benefit8: It is built right here in Copenhagen.

technical.headline: Technical Detail
technical.description: We use a mix of Large Language Models for reasoning and deterministic code for execution. The agents can propose actions, but they execute them through strict interfaces. This hybrid approach keeps the creativity of AI but limits the risk of unintended actions.

cta.headline: Deep Dive
cta.description: We are happy to share more about our architecture and how we handle sandbox isolation.

hero.headline: The Team
hero.subtitle: Engineers and founders working on the next generation of security tools.

christoffer.title: Christoffer Dreist, CFO
christoffer.description: Managing operations and our partnerships within the EU.

careers.headline: Research & Engineering
careers.intro: We are a small team. We care about clean code, reading papers, and solving hard problems.
careers.noPositions: Check back soon for new opportunities
careers.thesisDescription: We work closely with the university. If you are writing a thesis on Multi-Agent Systems or Explainable AI, we might be a good home for your research.
careers.futureTitle: Future roles we are planning for
careers.interestedDescription: We are always interested in meeting people who are obsessively curious about this tech.

visuals_compliance.audit_log: [VISUAL_PLACEHOLDER: An animation of a document being 'stamped' or verified. It represents the transition from raw data to a compliance-ready report.]

nis2.headline: NIS2 & Auditing
nis2.description: Regulations like NIS2 are shifting the focus from 'being secure' to 'proving you are secure'. Our platform is designed to generate that proof.
nis2.risk: Continuous Validation: We test defenses regularly, not just once a year.
nis2.incident: Evidence: Every simulation produces a log that can be shown to an auditor.
nis2.management: Traceability: We know exactly which agent did what, and when.
nis2.supply: Sovereignty: Our infrastructure is designed for European data requirements.

contact.headline: Start a Conversation
contact.description: We are busy building, but we make time for the right conversations. Whether it is a potential pilot or a research question, reach out.
contact.formSuccess: Thanks. We will be in touch.
